acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96-hour EC50 = 1.16 mg/L for algae (Scenedesmus) (IUCLID, 2000), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Between LD50 values of 768 mg/kg and 1010 mg/kg for rats (IUCLID (2000)), a value representing higher toxicity was taken into consideration for classification of the substance into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: The classification was based on the LC50 of 1.15 mg/L (217 ppm) for rats, which was obtained in a 4-hour exposure test (IUCLID (2000)). Given that its saturated vapour is 34000 ppm, in relation to the LC50 value of 217 ppm, the test was presumably conducted in a gaseous state.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Its rat LD50 was documented to be 550 mg/kg (Patty (2001)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: There is a study report in which mice were given a mixed diet containing the test substance and its nitrite salt for 12 months, as well as mice in other treatment groups receiving a diet supplemented with soybean or ascorbic acid (IUCLID (2000)). However, classification is not possible based on the results of this study.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its classification for acute toxicity is Category 2, and it is rapidly degradable (BOD: 83 and 95%, when the concentration of the test substance is 100 mg/L and following the standardized testing methods that include a 4-week test period and an activated sludge concentration of 30 mg/L (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1991); and log Kow = 2.83 (PHYSPROP Database, 2008)), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Its flash point is 39degC (UNRTDG (Rev. 15, 2007)), which is between 23 and 60degC.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: The classification is based on negative results obtained in an in vivo mutagenicity test using somatic cells (micronucleus tests using mouse bone marrow cells) (IUCLID (2000)). In addition to this study, in vivo gene toxicity test (inhibition of DNA-synthesis) gave negative results; regarding in vitro tests, Ames test yielded negative results while chromosomal aberration test produced positive results (IUCLID (2000)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Its autoignition point is 260degC (ICSC (1998)), which is above 70degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: In rabbit tests, the substance was reported to be severely irritating (IUCLID (2000)), and its pH was found to be 11.5 using a 5 g/L aqueous solution. It is classified into Category 1 for skin corrosion / irritation as well.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: The classification was based on the description that the substance is found to be corrosive in Draize tests using rabbits (IUCLID (2000)).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: A mouse ear swelling test found that this substance is not sensitizing (IUCLID (2000)). In addition, a patch test involving one person also found that the substance is not sensitizing (IUCLID (2000)). However due to insufficient data available, classification is not possible.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In the inhalation exposure test in which rats were exposed to 0.76-3.91 mg/L concentrations of the substance for 4 hours, surviving rats showed abnormal breathing and sneezing, while decedent rats showed congestion of the lungs and increased lung weights (IUCLID (2000)). The test concentrations fall under Category 1 guidance values.
